channel.name: How are AccountUpdates signed in mina?

messages.content:
So basically what I want to do is verify a signature of an AccountUpdate inside snarkyjs. 
I noticed that snarkyjs internally uses a lot of the "Ledger" class, which computes a so called transaction "commitment" and a full_commitment. How exactly are these computed? And could a signature on them be verified in snarkyjs?
@gregor
where `signature` is taken from `zkappCommand.feePayer.authorization`

Yeah but I need to verify them in-circuit, so mina-signer is no good. But I mean since snarkyjs Signatures are now the same scheme as mina-signer, it should be possible to verify them inside a circuit *theoretically*
I’ll need that as well (sooner rather than later) - so if you haven’t gotten to it I’ll expose it in snarkyjs
Haha for your rollup? 😄
Yea :D
Same lol
I thought so :D
I might get to it this weekend
Maybe a bit earlier
Don't worry, not a blocker on my side
oh I see, you need it in-circuit! it's true that `Signature.verify` is compatible with the way zkapp transactions are signed; however, `verify` only covers a subset of what is done

it should work like this:
* hash the zkapp tx in-circuit in a certain way to obtain the `fullCommitment`
* let the message be the single field element `[fullCommitment]`
* verify with `Signature.verify`
`fullCommitment` is a bit involved though

mina-signer implements it here: https://github.com/o1-labs/snarkyjs/blob/043903137af26e33a19fa24f2402bcbe4863514b/src/mina-signer/src/sign-zkapp-command.ts#L91-L104
so you either need to build a circuit which does the same, or expose the in-circuit version from OCaml

snarkyjs also has an in-circuit version of a considerable part of computing the commitment (the "call forest hash"): https://github.com/o1-labs/snarkyjs/blob/043903137af26e33a19fa24f2402bcbe4863514b/src/lib/account_update.ts#L1530

Ah that link is really helpful. I tried to decipher the ocaml implementation, but with not a lot of success. 
I already got the call forest hash in-circuit so I'll just use that for the depth-0 Aus as well. I still get different commitments on my implementation that the Ledger one, but I'll figure that out
